list_page_teaser: Luke Skywalker, Leia Organa, and Han Solo have different personalities, but get along very well.  Click to learn more!
description_html:
This gallery contains spiritual portraits of the main characters in the Star Wars Original Trilogy.

To see the personalities of some Jedi Masters and droids, see the Jedi Masters and droids gallery. To see the personalities of main characters in the prequel trilogy — including Darth Vader and Emporer Palpatine — see the prequel trilogy gallery on this site.
story_html:
These three people make a good team.

The Blue in Luke's spiritual portrait shows that he, with his Jedi training, is the deep, idealistic one. His image looks very similar to Yoda's and Obi-Wan Kenobi's.

The Green in Leia's spiritual portrait shows she is, by a small margin, the most decisive member of this group. Her very versatile, well-rounded personality makes it very easy for almost everyone to like her.

Meanwhile, the Yellow in Han's image shows he has the sharp awareness needed to support superior piloting skills, and the Red shows he is amiable and willing to help. His pragmatism and emotion — represented by the Yellow and Red — are the opposite of Leia's idealism and logic — represented by the Blue and Green — fueling a strong attraction.

To learn more about a character's personality, click on their thumbnail to see a larger version, then click on the Show the Whole Story button to read the character's story.

image_list.title: Han Solo
image_list.subtitle_html: Captain of the Millennium Falcon
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Han Solo's spiritual portrait shows he is down to earth and amiable.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Han's dominant personality trait, his realistic outlook and openness to new experiences.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Han demonstrates this trait when he initially refuses to help Luke, Leia, and the Rebel Alliance in Star Wars IV, A New Hope, thinking that their fight against the Empire is not realistic, and that he has more important things to do than help his new friends in their mission.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Han's auxiliary personality trait, his amiability, warmth, and friendliness.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Han demonstrates this trait when he has a change of heart and decides to return to help Luke, Leia, and the Rebel Alliance in their fight against the Empire, coming back to help destroy the Death Star near the ending in Star Wars IV, A New Hope.
image_list.story_intro_html:
When spaceship Captain Han Solo meets with Luke Skywalker and Obi-Wan Kenobi in the Mos Eisley Cantina — also known as Chalmun's Cantina — on Tatooine, he is totally unaware of just how life-altering the job he is taking on will be.

After a brief conversation and a murder, that may — or may not — be in self-defense, Han agrees to take Luke and Obi-Wan to Alderaan.

Han, the Cocky Scoundrel

To some, Han may be just a smuggler, but as the owner and Captain of the Millennium Falcon, it is evident he has a very high opinion of himself and his ship. Listening to Han boasting to Obi-Wan, one might even call him a bit cocky.

Han Solo: You've never heard of the Millennium Falcon?
Obi-Wan: No. Should I have?
Han Solo: It's the ship that made the Kessel Run in less than twelve parsecs.
 — From Episode IV: A New Hope, 1977.

When the responsible political leader Princess Leia meets him, she sees a scoundrel. The opposites in their personalities begin working their mutual attraction magic — and sparks start flying.

Han, the Skeptical Realist

Han Solo's spiritual portrait contains a lot of Yellow, representing his fairly strong preference for being practical and realistic. In this respect he's the opposite of Luke Skywalker, who is more idealistic, and whose portrait contains a lot of Blue.

Riding in the Millenium Falcon on their way to Alderaan, Han watches Luke practicing with a light saber while Obi-Wan Kenobi teaches him about the force. Han doesn't buy it:

Han Solo: Hokey religions and ancient weapons are no match for a good blaster at your side, kid.
Luke Skywalker: You don't believe in the force, do you?
Han: Kid, I've flown from one side of this galaxy to the other. I've seen a lot of strange stuff, but I've never seen anything to make me believe there's one all-powerful force controlling everything. There's no mystical energy field that controls my destiny. It's all a lot of simple tricks and nonsense.
 — From Episode IV: A New Hope, 1977.

Ignoring Han, Obi-Wan shows Luke how to use the force to predict and deflect the practice remote's firings even with his vision blocked. The skeptical Han attributes Luke's success to luck.

Romantic Tough-Guy

As a smuggler, Han Solo frequently has to deal with people who may be less than honorable. Therefore, he needs to maintain a tough-guy image — at least in his own mind.

Han: Look, your worshipfulness, let's get one thing straight. I take orders from just one person: me.
Leia: Hmm. It's a wonder you're still alive. Will somebody get this big walking carpet out of my way?
Han: No reward is worth this.
 — From Episode IV: A New Hope , 1980.

The two are constantly bickering, but at one point he reveals to Luke how he's really crushing on Leia.

Luke: I care. So. What do you think of her, Han?
Han: Trying not to, kid.
Luke: Good.
Han: Still, she's got a lot of spirit. I don't know, what do you think? Do you think a princess and a guy like me could –
Luke: No.
 — From Episode IV: A New Hope, 1977.

Han and Leia: Opposites Attract

The scoundrel and the logical, responsible one.

About This Portrait

This spiritual portrait is based on the Star Wars original trilogy:

  • Episode IV: A New Hope, 1977
  • Episode V: The Empire Strikes Back, 1980
  • Episode VI: Return of the Jedi, 1983
  • Episode VII: The Force Awakens, 2015

The book Star Wars Psychology: The Dark Side of the Mind, by Travis Langley and with a forward by Carrie Goldman, was also helpful in creating these portraits. This excellent book is a collection of immensely entertaining and enlightening essays and if you are a fan of Star Wars, I recommend it highly!
